citation.article-title: Thioalbus denitrificans gen. nov., sp. nov., a chemolithoautotrophic sulfur-oxidizing gammaproteobacterium, isolated from marine sediment
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Thioalbus denitrificans sp. nov.
Thioalbus denitrificans (de.ni.tri.fi′cans. N.L. part. adj. denitrificans from N.L. v. denitrifico, denitrifying).
Cells are Gram-reaction-negative, oxidase- and catalase-positive, aerobic, denitrifying, rod-shaped (0.5–0.8×1.2–1.5 µm) and have no flagellum.
Cells are able to oxidize thiosulfate, tetrathionate, sulfide and elemental sulfur but not sulfite under the denitrifying conditions.
Favourable growth occurs aerobically, forming circular colonies of ~0.7–1.5 mm diameter with regular edges within 10 days of incubation at 10–40 °C (optimum 28–32 °C).
Elemental sulfur is accumulated via thiosulfate oxidation when cells are grown under anaerobic conditions (Supplementary Fig. S1).

Does not use yeast extract, Tryptone, peptone, Casamino acids, succinate, glucose, glycerol, ethanol, methanol, pyruvate, malate, citrate, propionate, formate, proline, alanine, aspartic acid or serine as organic carbon sources or electron donors.
Growth factors, such as vitamins, are not required.
Optimum growth occurs at pH 7.0–7.5 and in 3% (w/v) NaCl.
Major cellular fatty acids are C16 : 0, C16 : 1ω7c/iso-C15 : 0 2-OH and C18 : 1ω7c/ω9t/ω12t.
The type strain, Su4T ( = KCTC 5699T = JCM 15568T), was isolated from a sulfur-oxidizing enrichment culture from marine sediment of the East Sea, South Korea.
The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 64.5 mol% (as determined by HPLC).
